quantityRules.description: Ball pythons are solitary and do NOT tolerate cohabitation. House individually only - minimum 120 gallons (48√ó24√ó24 inches). Cohabitation causes stress, competition, disease transmission, and potential cannibalism.

careTargets.gradient: Horizontal thermal gradient required (95-104¬∞F basking surface ‚Üí 86-90¬∞F warm hide ‚Üí 72-80¬∞F cool hide)

lifespan: 30+ years in captivity (commonly reach 40+ years with proper care)
temperament: Docile and calm, may ball up when stressed but rarely bites
originRegion: West and Central Africa (grasslands and forest edges)
setupTips: PVC front-opening enclosures are ideal - hold humidity better than glass, easier access than top-opening
Use halogen flood bulbs (90w PAR38 x2) as PRIMARY heat source - heat mats are supplemental only
Soil-based substrate (ReptiSoil, Eco Earth, or DIY 40% topsoil + 40% coco coir + 20% sand) 2-4 inches deep
BOTH warm hide (under basking) AND cool hide (opposite end) are mandatory - not optional
Large water bowl (8-10 inch diameter) on cool side for soaking
Provide climbing enrichment - cork bark, branches, ledges (debunks 'terrestrial only' myth)
Basking surface temp (95-104¬∞F) is CRITICAL for digestion - measure with infrared thermometer, not ambient air temp
notes: Crepuscular (active dawn/dusk) - NOT nocturnal as commonly believed
Very docile and handleable - rarely bite unless extremely stressed
Known for defensive curling into a ball when stressed (name origin)
Can be picky eaters and may fast seasonally (normal behavior - ball pythons fast 3-6 months safely if healthy weight)
Over 6500 morphs available - huge variety in colors/patterns
Adult size: 3-5 feet (males smaller 3-4', females larger 4-5')
Semi-arid to subtropical West African species (Ghana, Togo, Benin)

warnings.message: BASKING SURFACE TEMP 95-104¬∞F IS CRITICAL FOR DIGESTION. Measure with infrared thermometer on basking rock surface, not ambient air. Low temps (<85¬∞F) cause food to rot in stomach, leading to regurgitation or death.
NEVER use heat rocks - cause severe thermal burns. Heat mats are supplemental only (under warm hide if needed), NOT primary heat source. Use halogen flood bulbs as primary heat.

Cohabitation is NOT recommended despite being commonly attempted. Causes chronic stress, competition for resources, disease transmission, cannibalism, and breeding complications. Ball pythons are solitary‚Äîhouse individually.

Humidity measured inside cool hide (60-75%) - NOT at top of enclosure. Use digital hygrometer probe placed on substrate level. Low humidity (<45%) causes stuck sheds, dehydration, and respiratory moisture loss.

Ball pythons fast seasonally (1-6 months normal if healthy weight). Monitor weight monthly. Seek vet if: weight loss >10%, visible ribs, lethargy, regurgitation, or refusal >6 months with declining body condition.
40-gallon enclosures are OUTDATED. Modern standard is 120 gallons (48√ó24√ó24) minimum. Larger enclosures do NOT stress ball pythons if proper hides and clutter are provided.
Obesity is the #1 health issue in captive ball pythons. Adults (500-1500g) should eat every 14-21 days (10% body weight). Large adults (>1500g) every 28-56 days. Weekly feeding causes obesity.

feedingRequirements: Obligate carnivore - whole prey animals ONLY (rats, mice, ASF rats, quail, chicks)
VARIETY ESSENTIAL - rotate between rats (60-70% of diet), mice, ASF rats, quail, chicks (30-40%)
Frozen-thawed preferred over live prey (safer for snake, more humane)
10% body weight rule: Prey item(s) should total 10% of snake's weight
Prey size: No larger than 1.5x snake's girth at widest point
Thaw prey in warm water (100-110¬∞F) for 20-60 minutes, never microwave
feedingSchedule: Hatchlings (<5 weeks): Every 5 days, 10% body weight (hopper mice or rat pups)
Juveniles <200g (5 weeks-6 months): Every 7 days, 10% body weight (small adult mice)
Juveniles 200-350g (6-12 months): Every 7-10 days, 10% body weight (weaned rats)
Juveniles 350-500g (12-18 months): Every 10-14 days, 10% body weight (small rats)
Sub-adults/adults 500-1500g: Every 14-21 days, 10% body weight (medium rats)
Adults >1500g (large females): Every 28-56 days (4-8 weeks), 10% body weight (large rats)
Weigh snake monthly to adjust portions - visible ribs = underfed, fat rolls = overfed
waterNotes: Large water bowl essential - must be large enough for snake to curl up inside completely
Water bowl placement: Cool side (prevents excessive evaporation)
Change water DAILY (ball pythons often defecate in water bowls)
Scrub bowl with reptile-safe disinfectant 2-3x weekly
Bowl depth: 2-3 inches minimum for soaking
Ball pythons soak 1-3 hours before shedding (normal behavior)
mistingNotes: Mist 1-2x daily in moderate climates, 2-3x daily in dry climates
Target: 60-75% humidity in cool hide (measured with hygrometer probe on substrate level)
During shed cycle: Increase misting to achieve 65-70% humidity
Soil-based substrate (2-4 inches deep) is PRIMARY humidity management tool - holds moisture
Optional humid hide: Plastic hide box with damp sphagnum moss maintains 80-90% microclimate
PVC enclosures hold humidity 50% better than glass tanks
